title: Conflict Management
description: Discover your preferred style of handling conflict based on your instincts and reactions.

questions.question: When a disagreement arises at work, your first instinct is to…

options.A: Try to avoid the conflict and let it pass.
options.B: Seek a middle ground so everyone gives up something.
options.C: Assert your opinion strongly and push for your way.
options.D: Listen to all sides and work toward a win-win solution.
options.E: Give in to maintain peace, even if it costs you.

questions.question: A team member disagrees with your idea during a meeting. What do you do?

options.A: Stay quiet and avoid further discussion.
options.B: Ask them to explain and look for areas of agreement.
options.C: Defend your idea firmly to show confidence.
options.D: Suggest combining both ideas into a workable compromise.
options.E: Accept their idea to keep harmony in the team.

questions.question: Two colleagues are in conflict, and they approach you for help. How do you respond?

options.B: Encourage them to each give up a little to reach an agreement.
options.C: Support the colleague whose view you believe is stronger.
options.D: Facilitate a discussion to find a solution that satisfies both.
options.E: Urge one side to concede so things can move on quickly.

questions.question: When deadlines are tight and conflict arises, you are most likely to…

options.A: Ignore the conflict and focus only on the deadline.
options.B: Split the difference quickly to save time.
options.C: Push for your approach because speed matters.
options.D: Take time to involve everyone in finding the best solution.
options.E: Yield to others to avoid slowing things down.

questions.question: If someone criticizes your work unfairly, your reaction is…

options.A: Keep quiet and hope it goes away.
options.B: Try to calmly clarify misunderstandings and seek common ground.
options.C: Defend yourself strongly and challenge the criticism.
options.D: Invite a constructive discussion to resolve the issue.
options.E: Accept the criticism, even if it’s unfair, to avoid conflict.

questions.question: In a conflict, what matters most to you?

options.D: Creating a solution that benefits everyone.

questions.question: When conflict arises in a group project, you tend to…

options.A: Stay out of it and focus only on your part.
options.B: Suggest splitting tasks in a way that balances everyone’s concerns.
options.C: Push your idea until others agree.
options.D: Act as a mediator to find a solution that satisfies all.
options.E: Let others decide and just go along.

questions.question: You discover a mistake caused by a colleague. How do you handle it?

options.A: Ignore it—it’s not worth a fight.
options.B: Suggest a quick correction that shares responsibility.
options.C: Point it out firmly and insist they fix it.
options.D: Discuss it openly and find a solution together.
options.E: Fix it yourself to avoid confrontation.

questions.question: When you strongly disagree with your manager’s decision, you…

options.B: Propose an alternative that balances your view and theirs.
options.C: Voice your disagreement directly and argue your case.
options.D: Share your concerns respectfully and suggest a collaborative solution.

questions.question: Your general approach to conflict is best described as…

options.D: Collaborate to find the best outcome for all.

results.Avoiding: You prefer to step back from conflict. While this helps reduce stress, important issues may go unresolved.
results.Compromising: You look for middle ground. This is practical but may sometimes leave both sides partially dissatisfied.
results.Competing: You push strongly for your viewpoint. This shows confidence but may create tension if overused.
results.Collaborating: You value solutions that benefit everyone. This builds strong relationships but can take more time.
results.Accommodating: You prioritize harmony over winning. This preserves peace but may lead to your own needs being overlooked.
